results.title: Auxiliary views. Pt. 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
Begins by showing that the three principal views do not represent the true surface of an object that has one or more slanting faces. This condition is shown to require projection of the slanting surface on a plane which is parallel to it and is not one of the principle planes. This auxiliary projection is explained and defined. No other credits available.

results.title: Size description
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film presents the reasons why uniformity in dimensioning practices is essential, and explains that this uniformity depends on observance of certain standards in: 1. use of symbols; 2. choice of dimensions; 3. location of dimensions. The first step in learning this common language consists in extension lines, dimension lines, arrow heads, figures, notes, finish marks etc.

results.title: Language of drawing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film attempts to provide a sensible and acceptable answer to the question: “Why study mechanical drawing?” and to stimulate the beginning of students’ interest in the subject.

results.title: Shape description. Part 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film is designed as a sequel to “Shape description part 1” which presented the theory of orthographic projection. In part 2, the step-by-step procedure of constructing a drawing is demonstrated, and reasons for each step are explained.

results.title: Sections
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”

Some objects have important interior details which may show as a confused mass of dotted lines on the regular exterior views. The remedy for this is the sectional view, formed by the imaginary cutting away of part of the object to reveal interior details.

results.title: Automatic process control
results.brief_description: Illustrates the advantages to be derived from applying automatic control to a process in a small chemical plant. The four modes of control are discussed: on/off; proportional; proportional with reset; proportional with reset and rate action. An application of instrumentation for continuous process control is explained.
results.description: Illustrates the advantages to be derived from applying automatic control to a process in a small chemical plant. results.title: Autistic Syndrome 1
results.creator_credit: Stichting Film and Wetenschap Universitaire Film
results.brief_description: Presents some aspects of psychotherapy in a three year old autistic girl during her first year of residential treatment. We see her with her twin sister and with her therapist. A year later the twin sisters are observed with interest focused on changes in behaviour. No other credits available.
